items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendnet of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Accept Valenzuela/CAHSEE Williams Quarterly ReportBACKGROUNDThe Board of Trustees revised BP 1312 (Uniform Complaint Procedures) through the adoption of a BP 1312.1(a) Supplement and accompanying regulations.  This “supplement” section to BP 1312 incorporates the recent requirements of EC 35186 (Williams: SB550 and AB2727), which requires a different complaint form and timeline.  Additionally, it is required that staff bring to the Board of Trustees a quarterly report of Williams complaints filed and their current disposition.  The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from July 1, 2008 through September 30, 2008.  FISCAL IMPACT:Unknown at this time.FUNDING SOURCE:Senate Bill 6 (Williams)State Instructional Materials AllocationDistrict Instructional Materials BudgetOther Categorical funds as AppropriateRECOMMENDATION:The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering July 1, 2008 through September 30, 2008, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:Pending Board Vacancy:  Process for Appointment and Provisional Appointment to the Governing BoardBoard Member Shirakawa’s election to the County Board of Supervisors will result in a vacancy on the Governing Board for the remainder of Member Shirakawa’s term.Board Bylaw 9223 (a copy of which is attached) specifies the process for provisional appointments to the Governing Board.  Per Board Bylaw 9223, when a vacancy occurs four or more months before the end of a Board member's term, the Board shall, within 60 days of the date of the vacancy or the filing of the member's deferred resignation, either order an election or make a provisional appointment.  If no election is ordered, then the Board will make a provisional appointment.Board Bylaw 9223 specifies that the Board shall advertise in the local media to solicit “candidate applications or nominations.”  Thus, the Board must decide whether it will seek applications or nominations for the upcoming Board vacancy.  Per Board Bylaw 9223, the Board must also establish the timeline and the rules for the selection of the provisional appointees, and approve an application and a set of questions for all candidates to answer in writing.  The Board must also appoint an ad hoc committee consisting of less than a quorum of the Board to ensure that applicants are eligible for Board membership as required by law.  The applications of all eligible candidates will be forwarded to all Board members. The Board may appoint an advisory committee to, at a public meeting, review applications, interview candidates and make recommendations to the Board. The Board is not restricted by the advisory committee’s recommendation and may appoint any of the eligible applicants. The Board shall interview the candidates, of it’s choosing from the list of eligible applicants, at a public meeting, accept oral or written public input, and select the provisional appointee by a majority vote.FISCAL IMPACT:To be determined.FUNDING SOURCE:Not ApplicableRECOMMENDATION:Take action consistent with Board Bylaw 9223 to determine: (1) whether to seek applications or nominations to the pending Board vacancy; (2) authorize and direct Administration to advertise in the local media to solicit such applications/nominations to fill the pending Board vacancy; (3) determine the timeline and rules for the selection of the provisional appointee; and (4) approve an application and a set of questions for all candidates to answer in writing.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Recommendation Regarding Memorandum of Understanding to Explore the Joint Use of Sports Fields between East Side Union High School District and the City of San JoseThe East Side Union High School District currently provides athlete/sports fields for the primary use of the high school students attending the schools of the District.  The City of San Jose provides neighborhood parks and recreation facilities for use of the citizens of the City.  Capital funds available to improve and expand these assets are limited for both public agencies.  This Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) would put in place a cooperative relationship between both public agencies to explore the joint use of such assets to benefit the communities of both agencies.  Approving this MOU does not obligate either agency in any intrinsic or tangible way.  It merely sets forth and makes public the willingness to discuss the potential benefits of sharing resources. FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board approve the Memorandum of Understanding between East Side Union High School District and the City of San Jose to discuss joint venturing use of sports/athletic fields.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Genesis High SchoolBACKGROUNDAdministration is requesting that the Board of Trustees approve the transfer of forty-two (42) Genesis High School students to Apollo High School as a cost cutting measure due to low enrollment.  Genesis currently has forty-two students being supported by four teachers, one clerical staff member, and one administrator located at Evergreen Valley College.  The enrollment at Genesis enrollment has steadily decreased over the last three years and is not expected to reach the optimal target of eighty (80) students.  Apollo High School has recently added capacity to their campus and is able to handle the influx of Genesis students.  Students not wishing to transfer to Apollo High School may return to their home site or to one of the other two alternative high schools in the district. FISCAL IMPACT:Estimated Savings $200,000 FUNDING SOURCE:General FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the transfer of Genesis High School students to Apollo High School.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:Election of Representatives to County Committee on School District OrganizationOn November 26, 2008, an election will be held to seat three members on the Santa Clara County Committee on School District Organization.  The County Committee is made up of 11 elected members -- two members from each of the five county supervisorial districts and one at-large member. The primary responsibilities of the County Committee on School District Organization are the reorganization of school districts (through territory transfers and unification) and the establishment/rearrangement of governing board trustee areas in the school districts.Members are elected to four-year terms by representatives from the governing boards of the 36 Santa Clara County school districts (one vote from each district).FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:The Board may cast its ballot by majority vote for election of a candidate to the County Committee.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Approve the Change in Governance Structure of  MACSA Academia Calmecac Charter SchoolBACKGROUNDMACSA Academia Calmecac has requested that the original charter petition in Element 4 - “The Governance Structure of the School” be changed to reflect the new proposed duties and responsibilities of the school’s administration and the School Site Council.  The intent is to streamline the governance and accountability systems to provide consistent and meaningful staff and parent involvement. The request by MACSA Academia Calmecac is a non-substantial change to the original charter petition and is viewed as beneficial to the long term success of charter school.      FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the change in governance structure of MACSA Academia Calmecac Charter School.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO: Board of TrusteesFROM: Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY: Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT: Compliance with 10/08/04 Stipulated Arbitrator's AwardOn October 8, 2004, the District and the East Side Teachers Association were parties to a settlement agreement under the authority of Arbitrator Barbara Bridgewater.  In Section II, #16 of the Consent Award, the District agreed to provide a report to the Board of Trustees and to the Association President regarding the degree to which each comprehensive high school met its responsibilities under Article 15 of the Collective Bargaining Agreement.  This report is based upon data on day seventeen (17) of school, and includes for each schoolThe percentage of successful student placement on the last SASI master schedule runThe total number of classes over Article 15 limits not exempted by Article 15.8 limitsThe number of students with incomplete schedulesThe number of students upon which staffing projections were made and the actual number of students enrolledThe changes to sites' certificated FTE allocation since the first day of schoolThe number of students that have had class changes since the first day of schoolThe report contains data retrieved from the school sites, Technology Information Services, and the attendance accounting department.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the attached report.
items.item_text: Compliance with 10/08/04 Stipulated Arbitrator's Award
items.item_text_raw: 11.01 Compliance with 10/08/04 Stipulated Arbitrator's Award

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services and Dennis Barbata, Director of Information TechnologySUBJECT:Educational Technology PlanEducational Technology Plan 2009-2012The current Educational Technology Plan for ESUHSD expires in June 2009 and a new 3-year plan needs to be submitted to the CDE for approval by December 5, 2008.  As required by the State, the plan addresses the following areas:Using Technology to improve Teaching and LearningStudent Acquisition of Technology and Information Literacy SkillsAppropriate and Ethical Use of Information Technology in the ClassroomCyber SafetyImproved Record Keeping and Use of DataImproved two-way Home-School CommunicationsThe draft plan embodies the work of the Academic Master Plan and is available at: http://www2.esuhsd.org/TechPlan/TechPlan20092012.pdfEach District receiving  e-rate funds, Enhancing Education Through Technology (EETT) funds, and Microsoft Voucher reimbursement program needs to have a State Approved Technology Plan for the funding years.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services and John Torres, Energy ConsultantSUBJECT:Status Report on Energy Education Inc.The following is a cumulative summary of the District’s Energy Conservation Program covering the period January 2006 through September 2008.  The last report to the Board was given in January of 2006.  This summary only refers to energy savings related to electrical consumption.  On an annual basis we continue to use less electrical energy than we used in the base year of 2003.  This is even more significant when taking into consideration the District has increased facility square footage throughout and increased the number of electronic devices in our classrooms.
